metadata.title: PSI to kPa Converter – Pounds per Square Inch to Kilopascals
metadata.description: Convert psi to kPa (and kPa to psi) using NIST-traceable factors. Built for engineers, lab staff, and serious home cooks who need reliable pressure conversions for cylinders, autoclaves, HVAC, and recipes.

notes: Primary factor based on NIST General Tables of Units of Measurement: 1 psi ≈ 6.894757 kPa.
Values are rounded for on-screen readability; always keep extra significant figures in design and calibration work.

inputs.helperText: Enter gauge or absolute pressure in psi. The numeric conversion to kPa is the same; only the reference (atmospheric vs absolute zero) changes.

introduction.title: Convert PSI to kPa with engineering-grade confidence
body: This PSI to kPa converter is designed for situations where unit mistakes are not acceptable: gas cylinders, pressure vessels, HVAC systems, autoclaves, and lab or pilot-plant equipment. It uses the same conversion factors published in NIST’s General Tables of Units and the NIST SI guides, so the numbers you record in logbooks, batch records, or calibration sheets stay consistent with national metrology standards.

Whether you are an engineer checking a design pressure, a lab technician configuring a sterilization cycle, or a serious home cook following a pressure-based recipe, this tool gives you fast psi ⇄ kPa conversions plus the context you need to use them safely.

methodology.title: Methodology and conversion formula (psi → kPa)
body: Pressure is defined as force per unit area. In the International System of Units (SI), the coherent unit of pressure is the pascal (Pa), equal to one newton per square metre. The kilopascal (kPa) is 1000 Pa and is widely used in engineering, meteorology, and laboratory work.

In inch–pound practice, pounds per square inch (psi) represents one pound-force acting on an area of one square inch. It remains common in tire pressure ratings, compressed gas cylinders, and legacy process equipment.
This converter follows NIST’s General Tables of Units of Measurement for the relationship between psi and kPa:

These factors are consistent with NIST Special Publication 330 (The International System of Units), NIST’s Guide to the SI (SP 811), and the pressure unit tables reproduced in NIST technical references used by U.S. federal agencies and industry. University fluid mechanics courses, including MIT OpenCourseWare and other mechanical engineering programs, adopt the same relationships in worked examples and problem sets.
Internally, the calculator carries extra precision beyond what is displayed, so you can rely on stable results across repeated conversions and different rounding settings.

examples.title: Worked examples: psi to kPa in real-world contexts

items.label: Car tire rated at 35 psi
items.description: Many passenger vehicles specify tire pressures between about 30 and 35 psi on the door placard. 35 psi corresponds to roughly 241 kPa. Automotive manuals and some technical bulletins now list both psi and kPa, making a reliable converter essential when you work with mixed documentation.

items.label: Compressed gas cylinder at 2000 psi
items.description: A typical industrial gas cylinder can be filled to pressures in the range of 1800–2400 psi. 2000 psi is about 13,790 kPa. OSHA’s compressed gas requirements and university Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) programs expect cylinders, regulators, and relief devices to stay within their rated pressure in either unit system.

items.label: Laboratory autoclave at 15 psi gauge
items.description: A common sterilization cycle uses about 15 psi above atmospheric pressure, which is roughly 103 kPa gauge. Lab protocols and microbiology manuals often give target pressures in psi, while the autoclave’s pressure transducer and calibration certificate may be in kPa or bar.

items.label: Espresso machine specified at 9 bar
items.description: Service documents for espresso machines sometimes quote pump pressure in bar or psi, while component datasheets use kPa. 130.5 psi is approximately 899 kPa. Converting consistently helps you compare pump specs, pressure gauges, and manufacturer recommendations.

faqs.question: What is the exact formula to convert psi to kPa?
faqs.answer: This converter uses the NIST-based factor 1 psi (lbf/in²) ≈ 6.894757 kPa. The conversion formula is kPa = psi × 6.894757. The inverse relationship is psi = kPa × 0.14503774. These values come from NIST’s General Tables of Units of Measurement and are consistent with the SI guidance in NIST Special Publications 330 and 811.

faqs.question: Is the conversion different for gauge and absolute pressure?
faqs.answer: Numerically, the psi-to-kPa conversion is identical for gauge and absolute pressures—the factor between psi and kPa does not change. What changes is the reference point. Gauge pressure is measured relative to the surrounding atmosphere, while absolute pressure is measured relative to a perfect vacuum. If a datasheet says 15 psi(g), that means 15 psi above atmospheric pressure, which is roughly 103 kPa(g). To compare a gauge value with an absolute value, you must add or subtract atmospheric pressure (about 14.7 psi or 101 kPa at sea level).

faqs.question: Can I rely on this converter for safety decisions on cylinders and pressure vessels?
faqs.answer: Use this converter for unit consistency, not for final safety decisions. Whether a given pressure is acceptable depends on design codes, materials, temperature, corrosion allowance, and safety factors. Compressed gas cylinders and pressure vessels are regulated under standards and rules such as OSHA 29 CFR 1910.101 and industry codes adopted by EHS offices at universities. Always defer to the stamped nameplate, manufacturer documentation, and applicable standards—the converter simply helps you read those sources in the units you prefer.

faqs.question: Is this psi to kPa converter suitable for recipes and pressure cookers?
faqs.answer: Yes, as a numeric aid. Some high-end cooking references and food safety guidelines express pressure in kPa, while consumer cookbooks and online recipes often use psi. Many pressure cookers and canners have dials or digital controls in kPa or bar. Converting psi to kPa helps you align recipes with your specific device, but you must still follow validated time–temperature–pressure combinations from trusted food safety authorities and the appliance manufacturer.

faqs.question: How should I document psi and kPa during calibration?
faqs.answer: Good practice is to record both the value and the unit, along with the reference to your calibration standard. Accredited calibration labs and internal QA/QC groups often use NIST-traceable standards and cite NIST SI documents in their procedures. When you enter data into electronic logbooks or maintenance systems, using a consistent psi ⇄ kPa factor avoids rounding drift between different spreadsheets, calculators, or teams.

faqs.question: Why not convert psi directly to bar instead of kPa?
faqs.answer: Bar is a convenient engineering unit, but the pascal and its multiples (Pa, kPa, MPa) are the SI units recommended by NIST, ISO, and most university engineering programs. Converting psi to kPa keeps your calculations aligned with modern standards and makes it easier to combine pressure data with other SI-based quantities such as stress, energy, and specific volume.

summary.title: Summary: when to use psi vs kPa
body: Use psi when you work with legacy equipment, older U.S. documentation, or industries that still specify operating limits primarily in inch–pound units. Use kPa (or bar/MPa) when you prepare new engineering documents, lab protocols, or regulatory filings aligned with SI-based standards.

This converter gives you traceable psi ⇄ kPa numbers anchored in NIST and widely used in university curricula, so you can move between older and modern documentation without rewriting your entire workflow around a different unit system.

terms.definition: A non-SI pressure unit equal to one pound-force acting on one square inch of area. Common in tires, cylinders, and legacy U.S. equipment.
An SI-derived unit of pressure equal to 1000 pascals. Widely used in engineering, meteorology, and laboratory specifications.
Pressure measured relative to the surrounding atmosphere, often denoted as psig or kPa(g). Zero gauge pressure corresponds to local atmospheric pressure.
Pressure measured relative to a perfect vacuum, often denoted as psia or kPa(a). It is always greater than zero in real applications.
A calibration or measurement that can be linked through an unbroken chain of comparisons to standards maintained by the National Institute of Standards and Technology.
